Award.AwardTitle: BDD: Dynamic Evolution of Smart-Phone Based Emergency Communications Network

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Emergency communications networks are crucial for reaching out and helping affected people during long-persisting disasters such as the Tohoku earthquake in Japan or Hurricane Katrina in the US. Because of the ubiquitous availability of smartphones, it is important to integrate them into the emergency communications network consisting of both surviving cellular network and deployed emergency communications infrastructure. All these components vary in their ability to provide necessary communications as the disaster unfolds. It is therefore essential to continuously monitor and ``tune'' the network to provide the best possible coverage and communications capability.

This project explores how to interconnect clusters of smartphones via WiFi tethering technology and integrate them with the deployed emergency network. Since the densities of people and hence of smartphones can vary substantially over the affected area, the project will explore mechanisms to conserve battery and other smartphone resources by exploiting overlap/redundancy in the sensed data. Another key issue addressed by the project is the evolution of the emergency network as the disaster situation itself evolves. The project analyzes data obtained from twitter during the disaster in order to get insights into how the network should evolve. Furthermore, the project examines how to deploy the mobile access points initially and later move them to tune the network to the needs of the evolving disaster. The analysis of twitter data involves several bigdata challenges including classification, prioritization, and ordering of tweets so the interpretation and decision making -- which is still expected to be done by humans -- is considerably simplified.

The rapidly increasing penetration of smart phones that carry a wide array of sensors makes them ideal for disaster communications. In addition, twitter has established itself as the premier human communication mechanism during disasters owing to its modest technological requirements and ease of use. This project takes these phenomena and stitches them together to create an agile disaster communications network that can provide significant additional value in quickly reaching affected people and collecting crucial data for rushing the required assistance to them. As a part of US-Japan joint program, with research teams from Temple University in the United States and Aizu University in Japan, the project will develop technologies that will be of direct relevance to both countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the project was to study how to integrate smartphones into the emergency response network and how to evolve this network as the disaster itself evolves. The network evolution is facilitated by both the data collected through the network itself, and by exploiting the twitter messages that relate to the disaster and corresponding needs for further information gathering and assistance.  The network evolution also needs physical evolution of the infrastructure in form of mobile access points suitably located to support the smartphone ad hoc network.  Another aspect studied was to reuse the audio sensors of smartphone to validate the liveness of audio source and exploit the perturbation of wireless signals to localize people in disaster zone who may not be carrying a working smartphone.

The major outcome of the project was to quantify how well an ad hoc network built from smartphones can work in areas with lost network connectivity. Our effort concentrated around using the WiFi hot-spot capability that is available in nearly every smartphone sold today. We also exploited the universally deployed wireless emergency alerting (WEA) service to initiate building of the ad hoc network and ultimately connecting it to the smartphones that are located in the operational part of the cellular network. Our work has demonstrated that this is a workable approach, however, there are several challenges that were unclear at the outset. First, in spite of the universality of WiFi hotspot technology, each smartphone implements it in a somewhat different way, which make the interoperability a substantial issue. Consequently, real deployments would need further standard APIs across multiple smartphone brands. Second, the use of WiFi hot spot requires that one device be in hot-spot mode while the other is in client mode; this leads to long mode switching delays and thus requires setting up an entire path in advance of bulk transfer of (accumulated) data rather than packet by packet. We can however, deal with the evolution of the disaster and mobility quite well using grid-quorum based mechanism for establishing ad hoc connections.

Since Twitter is very popularly used in disaster scenarios, an accurate and efficient analysis of Twitter messages is essential for situational understanding. We showed that by recognizing and classifying concepts rather than words, it is possible to develop a better understanding of Twitter conversations. Such an analysis can also provide an assessment of network connectivity issues which can be helpful in the deployment of additional assets for communication. Obviously, no tweets will be generated from areas that have no connectivity at all; however, in practice, network outages are scattered and simple services such as SMS are still operational. The primary difficulty in using the Twitter data is that only a miniscule percentage of users enable location information. The Twitter data is also useful in establishing other issues faced by the affected people (e.g., no power, need for water, food, medicine, etc.), but this requires an estimate of how long stated need remains active, since the users will usually not continue to retweet the same demands.

The passive health monitoring part of the project has shown that we can recognize sign language with 87% accuracy with transmitter continuously sending packets to the receiver which are perturbed by the sign gestures. In another result, we are able to identify liveness of human voice with 94% accuracy. This is important in a disaster scenario to recognize live human voices from people in need from recorded or played voices.
